texts.definition: Games that during gameplay adjust their difficulty depending on how well players progresses.
markups: <style="Definition">Games that during gameplay adjust their difficulty depending on how well players progresses.</style>

Providing the right level of challenge for players in a game can be difficult for game designers to achieve solely through creating challenges in advance. While they can let players have influence on this, e.g. through a scale of difficulty settings or by choosing their opponents, <style="CurrentLink">Dynamic Difficulty Adjustment</style> is rules in the game system that adjusts players' challenges depending on how well they are gaming.
There is a US patent related to <style="CurrentLink">Dynamic Difficulty Adjustment</style>.

<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Borderlands">Borderlands</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Fallout%203">Fallout 3</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Oblivion">Oblivion</link></style> all uses <style="CurrentLink">Dynamic Difficulty Adjustment</style> systems to within certain limits scale the strength of enemies to those of the players.

While changing this is quite natural for these combat-oriented games, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Racing%20Games">Racing Games</link></style> such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Mario%20Kart%20series">Mario Kart series</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Super%20Monkey%20Ball%20series">Super Monkey Ball series</link></style> instead typically increase the maximum speed of the last racers to help that player catch up.

<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Board%20Games">Board Games</link></style> can also have <style="CurrentLink">Dynamic Difficulty Adjustment</style> systems. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Shadows%20over%20Camelot">Shadows over Camelot</link></style> increases the difficulty of other challenges when quests are solved, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Battlestar%20Galactica:%20The%20Board%20Game">Battlestar Galactica: The Board Game</link></style> has mechanisms for balancing gameplay halfway through game instances when playing with a odd number of players.

<style="CurrentLink">Dynamic Difficulty Adjustment</style> is in <style="Link"><link="single-player-games">Single-Player Games</link></style> used to try and reach a certain level of challenge, possibly set by players through <style="Link"><link="difficulty-levels">Difficulty Levels</link></style>, while for <style="Link"><link="pvp">PvP</link></style> it is instead used to achieve <style="Link"><link="player-balance">Player Balance</link></style>. In games with <style="Link"><link="tvt">TvT</link></style>, <style="CurrentLink">Dynamic Difficulty Adjustment</style> systems are also applied to achieve <style="Link"><link="team-balance">Team Balance</link></style>. A prime choice for these systems are if they should be possible to turn on and off, i.e. if they are <style="Link"><link="optional-rules">Optional Rules</link></style> - if always active they may not be revealed to players to give them an <style="Link"><link="exaggerated-perception-influence">Exaggerated Perception of Influence</link></style>. One reason to make them optional is that they can they work as a form of <style="Link"><link="difficulty-levels">Difficulty Levels</link></style>; another reason to make <style="CurrentLink">Dynamic Difficulty Adjustment</style> systems optional is that the decrease the <style="Link"><link="value-effort">Value of Effort</link></style> possible in games.

The main way of achieving <style="CurrentLink">Dynamic Difficulty Adjustment</style> is through <style="Link"><link="negative-feedback-loops">Negative Feedback Loops</link></style>, typically by measuring gameplay progress and then giving <style="Link"><link="decreased-abilities">Decreased Abilities</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Increased%20Abilities">Increased Abilities</link></style> as appropriate. Common examples are affecting how <style="Link"><link="damage">Damage</link></style> is given or received, and affecting top speed for <style="Link"><link="movement">Movement</link></style>. Number of <style="Link"><link="enemies">Enemies</link></style> and the performance of these and <style="Link"><link="ai-players">AI Players</link></style> are other design solutions used frequently. A low key way of providing <style="CurrentLink">Dynamic Difficulty Adjustment</style> is to give failing players <style="Link"><link="clues">Clues</link></style> on how to progress better.

While all games can have <style="CurrentLink">Dynamic Difficulty Adjustment</style>, <style="Link"><link="dedicated-game-facilitators">Dedicated Game Facilitators</link></style> can do them secretly and without causing any extra <style="Link"><link="excise">Excise</link></style> to players and <style="Link"><link="game-masters">Game Masters</link></style> can do the adjustment on the fly depending on the specific context of gameplay.

When optional, <style="CurrentLink">Dynamic Difficulty Adjustment</style> is typically selectable through <style="Link"><link="secondary-interface-screens">Secondary Interface Screens</link></style> but in other cases they may be completely hidden from players.

In <style="Link"><link="single-player-games">Single-Player Games</link></style>, <style="CurrentLink">Dynamic Difficulty Adjustment</style> acts as a <style="Link"><link="balancing-effects">Balancing Effect</link></style>, not necessarily making gameplay even between players and the system but towards reaching <style="Link"><link="casual-gameplay">Casual Gameplay</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="challenging-gameplay">Challenging Gameplay</link></style> depending on the game design. If players can choose to have <style="CurrentLink">Dynamic Difficulty Adjustment</style> it can due to this function as <style="Link"><link="difficulty-levels">Difficulty Levels</link></style> and can also help preserve a sense of <style="Link"><link="value-effort">Value of Effort</link></style>. In games with <style="Link"><link="pvp">PvP</link></style> the systems can give rise to <style="Link"><link="player-balance">Player Balance</link></style> and in games with <style="Link"><link="tvt">TvT</link></style> gameplay, <style="Link"><link="team-balance">Team Balance</link></style>. For games with <style="Link"><link="drop-in-drop-out">Drop-In/Drop-Out</link></style> support, the latter also gives players a <style="Link"><link="freedom-choice">Freedom of Choice</link></style> to game less depending on how this will affect the other players.

Systems for <style="CurrentLink">Dynamic Difficulty Adjustment</style> are <style="Link"><link="balancing-effects">Balancing Effects</link></style>, both in themselves and as examples of <style="Link"><link="handicap-systems">Handicap Systems</link></style>. They can give players <style="Link"><link="exaggerated-perception-influence">Exaggerated Perceptions of Influence</link></style>, if not revealed to them. If they are known to players this may still occur by this is a volatile state - if may just as easily work against it if players can note specific cases when the system rather than the player had the deciding effect. When <style="CurrentLink">Dynamic Difficulty Adjustment</style> systems forcefully but secretly change outcomes of game events, they give rise to <style="Link"><link="fudged-results">Fudged Results</link></style>.
